Hi All  
This thread is really warming up lovely some great stuff here for sure, hopefully all us 1 minute traders can help each other become better traders.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/263a-fe0f.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f4ad.png?v=15.1)  
  
Anyway found my top 8 trender indy from the platform so here it is.  
  

Attached File(s)

![File Type: ex4](https://assets.faireconomy.media/images/attach/ex4.gif) [#Top 8 Trenders Indicator.ex4](/attachment/file/1423878?d=1399681614) 23 KB | 1,767 downloads 

  
  
But before I go any further must give credit to the creator of this indy who worked with me to put this together, Hugh Briss, otherwise known as Ted to his close friends![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f917.png?v=15.1). He is a great guy and coder so if you have any ideas you want coding have a chat with him. I'm sure for the right price he will help you out. Thanks Ted great job.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44f.png?v=15.1)  
  
Oh and he has written a book about trading too, smart guy, heres a link to his book. [http://www.amazon.com/Swing-Trading-...nd+stochastics](http://www.amazon.com/Swing-Trading-Heiken-Ashi-Stochastics-ebook/dp/B00JHR49T0/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1396821456&sr=8-1&keywords=swing+trading+with+heiken+ashi+and+stochastics)  
  
I will endeavour to explain how it works and the best way I've found to use it but I will say it could be used in numerous ways so heres my ideas.  
  
Basically it measures the steepness of a moving average (you can choose which one) then ranks them in order of steepness so the steepest is at the top. The theory is that the fastest moving pairs, trending the most, will have the steepest sloping MA. We monitor 2 timeframes so you can monitor the timeframe above the one you trade. This is useful for a couple of reasons you can either trade the pair when it comes to the top on both or another way I use it is when the same pair is top in both but opposite colours eg going in opposite directions which means a reversal is imminent.  
  
The whole point of following steep sloping MA's is that when you trade with the trend not only will the momentum carry you to profit quicker but also the momentum indicators work really well giving you a higher strike rate. The GBPUSD daily chart below,for instance, gave you 8 winning entries out of 10.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: top 8 trender chart.png
Size: 50 KB](/attachment/image/1423851/thumbnail?d=1399674144)](/attachment/image/1423851?d=1399674144)   

  
  
So how does it help? Well first of all look at the top 8 trenders in the daily column and use it as your first filter, go down the list checking out the charts until you see one you like the look of. I liked the look of the gbpusd daily chart(see attached), the red MA is a 100lwma which is the MA used in this example, as you can see GBPUSD is 3rd in our table of top 8 trenders. Check out the others yourself I think theres 4 of the 8 that look really tradable in my opinion.  
  
Now we have our pair to trade and look for a good entry to join the trend.  
  
I like the look of the 1.6800 level for Monday don't you???  
  
So how do we set up the inputs?? See top 8 trenders settings hrly and daily attachment below.  
  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: top 8 trenders settings hrly and daily.PNG
Size: 28 KB](/attachment/image/1423857/thumbnail?d=1399674892)](/attachment/image/1423857?d=1399674892)   

  
  
the top 2 inputs are used to space out the table x and y position the indicator on your chart the 5th one is fontsize.  
  
tf1 = timeframe 1 in minutes eg 15 = 15min 60 = hrly 1440 = daily 10,080 = weekly 43,200 = monthly etc  
tf2 = timeframe 2 as above  
tf1malength = timeframe 1 moving average period  
tf1type = 0-simple 2-ema 3-lwma 4-smoothed  
tf1maprice = timeframe 1 moving average price applied to 0-close 1-open 2-high 3-low etc  
tf1lookback = this is how far you want to look back the moving average to measure the slope. I use a multiple of next timeframe up for 60min I use 24 as 24 hours in a day; for 1 min I use 15 as 15min is next timeframe up. Please try out different periods at your discretion.  
tf2 settings are the same as above but just for the higher timeframe.  
useatr = this is an interesting one where you can choose to take into account the pairs atr so giving it a volitility filter, without it just the biggest movers, most volitile pairs come to the top. I personally set it to false for lower timeframes like 1 min etc but 1 hr and above I set it to true. But again play around with it yourselves see what siuts you best.  
  
Ok so thats the settings now the difficult part, how best to use it?? Heres some of my ideas:  
  
**_Straight forward trade the trend using cci for entries._**  
  
Look at the chart above and you can see that GBPUSD is in the top 3 so check out the chart and look for a CCI signal back with the trend. I use a 8 CCI as pullbacks in a strong trend can be quite small, I also wait for the CCI to go over -100 level to qualify as an entry. Once cci goes over -100 then wait for first smaller cci candle eg momentum is slowing down and looking to reverse. Place a pending order above the signal candle and see if it gets hit next day, if not and cci candle is smaller than yesterdays then move pending order to next daily candle, continue until trade is hit.  
  
Exit at your discretion or hold until the trend ends. Trail all entries up higher lows until stopped out. Or just grab each momentum move at your discretion.  
  
**_Heres a 1 minute trade example_**  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: 1 min example.png
Size: 41 KB](/attachment/image/1423868/thumbnail?d=1399677422)](/attachment/image/1423868?d=1399677422)   

  
  
This time the top 8 trender is set up for 1 minute and 5 minute and looking at 1 min you can see its showing top of the trenders but more importantly you can see why look at the 100lwma (red ma) its sloping down perfectly, I tend to use 14 cci on the lower timeframes but theres a nice signal at 11.03 which is also a break and retest of my 200sma, one of my favourite entries, and away you go!!  
  
Exit again is discretionary but heres a couple of choices for you;  
  
First green Hieken ashi candle trail stop to top.  
The next support level in this case the yellow line (yesterdays close)  
Exit first TP at either above and hold 2nd half until 100lwma is crossed over.  
  
**_Reversal setup_**  
  
This is one of my favourite setups usually occurs mid morning on a London Openwhen price has been racing one way for 100pips or so appearing in the top 8 for most of the morning as say red (going down) it will also be in the top 8 of the 5 min trenders too. Wait for it to appear in the 1 min top 8 trenders as opposite colour to 5 min eg Green, then enter as above theres every chance it will go back 70% of the move down.  
  
**_London breakout strategy/ post news strategy_**  
  
London is when a lot of money comes to the table and often causes a breakout in one pair or another. Well what better way than to see which 100lwma is pouring up or down the page 30 mins after the open??? Look at the top 3 trenders and checkout the chart for a good setup , I like break and retests of key levels as discussed before eg. 25 levels, 200sma, yesterdays high,low close or the daily pivot. oh and of course S and R levels.  
  
The same theory can be applied to a high differential news release, wait for 10 mins after the news release for price action to settle down and a new 1 min trend to setup again which 100lwma is sloping the steepest??? The MA can be changed to say a 20 for an immediate response after news but I find a bit too jumpy for normal trading.  
  
  
**_SUMMARY_**  
  
Basically the top 8 trender can be used on any timeframe to identify the strongest moving pairs on that timeframe. When used on the 1 minute timeframe you will find it chops and changes quite a bit so sometimes use the 5 min as your master and wait for 1 min to agree. The bottom line is its an awesome indicator but thats it, its just an indicator you still have to check the chart out and look for a siutable entry, but trust me once you learn how to use it it can be a great help.  
  
One word of warning sometimes when a pair comes to the top it can have already moved quite away so might be about to reverse, so again use your skills to decide whether that pairs worth trading or not. best time for me is when the 100lwma has just turned up or down after a strong move one way or the other, thats when its the best time to get in and hold.  
  
Well that's me done I'm sure theres all sorts of ways to make use of this indy so good luck and if it helps you become a better trader then don't forget to thank Ted, Hugh Briss, without his coding skills it wouldn't be here.

Glad you are enjoying the top 8 trender it can certainly help and I think its a good idea to use the 5 min as the master then look for your favourite entries in the 1 min. Don't forget you can use it on higher timeframes too eg daily as master and trade the hourly.  
  
Just a word of warning don't forget all trends come to an end and usually before its shown in the MA so whenever you look at a top trender make sure its still trending strongly and not looking like its exhausted eg was the last push higher a clear push higher?? Is it pulling back to support etc etc I always say to people don't just trade it because its in the top 8 trenders, still use your analysis skills to confirm the trends still going.  
  
And to answer your question the lookback period is 15 bars but of course you can set it for what you want I just use the next timeframe up for my own use please feel free to experiment.  
  
Sorry Rooi no trading from me today had an early business meeting with my partner who has just launched her own weight loss group, exciting times all round at the mo.

Hi  
  
Just looked back at this mornings charts and saw a setup that I really like so thought I would share it with you all. Its the London mid morning reversal. When the London boys set us all up for a fall by letting price march one way right into all thier orders waiting to eat us alive.  
  
Thing is by trading the 1 min charts you can sometimes see it happening and jump on board. I watch for 2 things really.  
  
1) A pair to appear in the top 8 trenders one colour say green, going up, then an hour later it appears red, going down.  
  
2) I watch for my 15 min CCI to turnover then take the next 2 or 3 1 min cci signals the same way as per charts below.  
  
It happened on EURAUD this morning and gave us a perfect pullback entry at 10.50 gmt to a 25 level (1.4725)  
  
Its gone down about 75 pips since.  
  
  
By the way watch out for New York reversing this move, I have a personal theory that London and New York have an agreement that one sells something all morning whilst the others buy it all back in the afternoon, that way they both make bucket loads of money. Seen it happen all too often for it to be a coincidence.  
  
So watch for the reversal back up this afternoon. Just a thought.  
  
EDIT; Sorry just realised I showed the GBPAUD chart from this morning but at least it shows the EURAUD in the top 8 trenders for 1 and 5 mins.

Hi Clivepackham, whichever signal comes first between EJ & GU does it for me. (normally set up and watching around 15/30 mins before FO)  
I use 2 exits, 1st TP is +7/8 or more if the market gifts it, TP2 exit at discretion around any weakness of signal, barrier, news etc. I tend to close out TP2 if it's anywhere near my daily target and showing any sign of weakness, like today.  
I never ever pre-suppose/expect/anticipate/hope any trade will be a runner, not on 1min.   
All the best, strada.

As per request by PM I will share entry system that I use.  
  
I use the color change on the matrix together with the bars at the bottoms color change   
  
Once the color change happens there should be a 1 pip improvement of the of the signal bar   
  
Not all entries are going to be profitable and working out the best entries are up to you and how you like to trade  
  
The rest of the info is all in the thread to read and there are plenty of examples.I suggest digesting Strada's charts as that is what I do.  
  
The most important of the system is to make your wins bigger than your losers.There will be plenty of loser but you are able make money by keeping them small.  
  
The vertical lines shows possible trades for today  
  
Hope this helps.  
  
PS- Dont be afraid to ask questions on the thread as nobody will think strange of it.Its is afterall why we are all here.To share and to learn.

However, I do this having analysied the contracts that I am trading hour by hour over several months, so that I know when each frequently moves and by how much and also the overall morning and afternoon swings, as I treat the European morning and US morning as two separate sessions.  
  
This allows me to focus on just the three pairs and two **major** crosses that historically offer tradeable moves during my chosen trading hours.....I would have to do a great deal of research to justify adding any additional contracts and I personally would NOT be able to cope with any more and remain focused.....for me, less is better.  
  
I would also look carefully at some of the thinly traded crosses being mentioned.....what is the typical range of their [spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide") and how much slippage is to be expected etc.....![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f914.png?v=15.1)

Yes, it's galling if you're taken out at BE then the trade develops and leaves you on the sidelines.  
BUT, consider the alternatives. If you let price slip through your BE stop how far do you let it go? You may by this stage be already in a signalled reverse move, not only are you losing money, you've denied yourself the opportunity of making profit on the reversal.  
Plus preserving your capital in this way is as good as a good trade, it is a "position".  
Very often when you're taken out at BE the signal that took you into the trade initially will have broken down. If the move re-establishes itself it's quite likely that a new signal will form giving you the opportunity to re-enter either the full trade or just the TP that exited at BE.  
All in all, over the term, I've found it a very beneficial rule, but it still hurts when I'm out and the trade goes on to great profit. Sometimes I do break the rule and allow a little flexibility on those days when I think I'm smarter than the market. Invariably I get a sore backside!!  
Strada.  
@ Jonnypants ~ daily "target" is around 20 but I'm flexible on that, some days I have to settle for +1, and do my best not to have any losing days. Strict believer in the market will only give what it wants to give, so it's up to me to manage my trades within those parameters.

Hi Jeffray  
  
As per usual when I try to hold a trade it went up about 10 pips then came back and stopped me out at BE.  
  
Funny thing is yesterday if I had held half my entries I would of made hundreds of pips. Its almost like the market knows when I'm holding and knows when I'm folding.  
  
I am constantly working on improving my strategies and how I carry them out so looking to make changes for Monday.  
  
Basically I am going to bank half after 8-10 pips , when the momentum subsides from first push. Will watch tick box for a stall.  
  
Then move other half to BE and leave it to run or stop out at BE. Will hold until 1 min trend ends eg trail up HL's or trail down LH's until stopped out. Might even add on if signals carry on.  
  
Well thats the plan but will I have the discipline to follow it through?? Now as we all know,when it comes to trading, thats the million dollar question!!!!

No of course I don't mind, its demo at the moment as experimenting with some new strategies on the 1 min charts, but looking to go live again next week if I get some positive results this week.  
  
Basically I am trying to catch the London breakout trades by taking entries in the strongest trending pair through the London open. My theory is whichever 100 lwma is sloping the steepest then thats where the London money is going so jump on board grab a handful of pips with the first push then hold 2nd TP until the trend finishes.  
  
Well thats the theory, But as I aptly demonstrated this morning and as the chart below shows, even on demo its hard to hold until the trend ends. If I had held I would of been close to 130 pips up (had 2 trades open) and still holding.  
  
Trouble is you have so many trades that don't go and you see all your profit disappear, that when you do catch one its hard to hold it???  
  
Oh well work in progress but when I do go live will start my own thread,rather than post all over yours, and fully intend to post a trade explorer so everyone can see how hard it is. LOL.

Feel free to post here as often as you want.  
  
Very nice trading.  
  
I suggest to keep your winner and scale out as well if you like that sort of thing.Im working on keeping my winner as well  
  
I did trade a trend system in the past and I can suggest that you split your trade in 2 positions of 0.05 each = 0.1  
  
Then TP 1 = 8 pips @ 0.5  
  
TP 2 then gets split into 5 X 0.01 lots  
  
For example  
  
TP 2.1 = 10 pips  
TP 2.2 = 12 pips  
TP 2.3 = 15 pips  
TP 2.4 = 20 pips  
TP 2.5 = a reversal of the MA's or change of CCI  
  
You will have a lot of BE trades though that is just how it is with trend trading IMHO  
  
All tps are relative to your SL  
  
TP1 should equal your SL at the very least to give you a minimum of 1:1 R:R  
  
BUT , there is plenty to consider as should be relative to the ATR of the pair your trading (plenty of back testing though )  
  
Just my 2 cents and please feel free to ignore it completely.

Hi Clive, hope you don't mind me joining in this discussion, you raise some important points worthy of some open discussion.  
Trend is a very large part of many traders' decision making process, and understandably so. However, it doesn't have the same level of importance to everyone. I for one rarely ever use it.  
  
Let me say straight away here, that does not make either of us wrong, it just means we have different perspectives and trading mentalities both of which could be as good (or bad) as each other.  
  
Everyone has to somehow prove that whatever method/strategy they intend to use is going to be profitable. As you said, your winners have to yield more than your losers. So we all achieve our chosen strategies with this common goal. BUT, we all do this differently. Many will do it as you have chosen, ie using trend in the belief that your entries will have a decent probability of profit. As I said earlier there is nothing wrong with that, I have no criticism to make. If you can create a consistent profitable strategy around this criteria and it is working for you, you're comfortable with it, then you've cracked it, you will enjoy profitable trading.  
  
The point to be made here is that "trading with trend" isn't the only way, it isn't exclusive to profitable trading, there will always be numerous ways to trade any good method some of which will be very adaptable and others that may well respond better to trending markets, S&R, Pivots etc.. In much the same way as some will say you can't make profit trading 1min you have to trade daily or 4hour charts etc., it really is up to the individual to find their own comfort level with trading and that will come in as many varieties as there are people. It doesn't run that only one way can be right.  
  
The only "wrong" methods/strategies are those that consistently lose money.  
  
Developing a strategy for consistent profit on 1m t/f isn't easy, it has some very distinct characteristics and behaviour which all has to be factored in. You are clearly working hard to find the optimum strategy for you based on trend, I'm sure you'll succeed with that and I wish you every success with it.   
strada.

Yea I guess I am just trying to make money fast,hence the 1 minute timeframe. I try to only take AAA+ rated entries and cut my losers very quickly. I try to only ever lose 10 pips max and very often cut them before that soon as they turn against my trade idea.  
  
It would be nice to just make 10 pips per day equals 10% then call it a day like our friend punisher does. Its all about personal discipline I guess which is very important just like money management.  
  
Talking about money management thats another key thing to only trade 1% of your outstanding balance, win or lose, that way you can guarantee you won't blow your account as its absolutely impossible to run out of money that way. You could trade and lose every trade for the rest of your life and still not run out of money. Sure it gets pretty small after say 20 losers in a row, but one would like to think you would review your strategy before that happens??? LOL. (still no smiley faces!!!)  
  
The piont is if your trading strategy has a positive edge you should make nice returns no matter how much you risk. That being said I am considering reducing it to say 0.2% per pip to help with the emotions, in fact when I go live will probably start off using 0.2% per pip and work it up as I get more confident.  
  
Mind you, saying that, yesterday I had a tremendous afternoon and doubled my demo account, took some riskier trades though but then thats what its all about with demo trying out different entries etc. Been trying out lots of different things this week but slowly slowly its all coming together nicely. Gonna keep it simple for next week , write out my rules and stick to them like glue.  
  
Well thats the plan, but as we all know its one thing to write out a good trading plan but another thing altogether to actually trade it!!!  
  
Anyway sounds like you are getting it together nicely, how do you decide when to stop? When is enough enough for you???

Hi Clive  
  
You are very right about the process of it, if your strategy has an edge you will be able to make nice returns.There is nothing wrong with being aggressive and trading with 10% of your capital per trade. If you have $1000 and trade 1 % of your account at 10 pips stop your risk is $10 so $1 per pip  
  
But if you have a $1000 dollars in your account for trading and you take 10% of the account and put it in a a trading account it is $100 and trade it 10% risk it also works out to $1 per pip but your growth is much faster right, with less risk on your money in the bank but more risk on the amount in trading account using leverage.  
Your thinking to yourself I know this Rooi and Im sure you do.  
  
So why are we not all billionaires? Because of the pain it causes us when we lose 10% of the account.  
Why does it cause us pain? Because we have not tested our system to the point where we can trust it enough to get us through the doubt of making the next trade.  
  
If one can trade for a year using the same system on the same market and produce a certain outcome and work out the draw down and the different stats about the system and your trading then the sky is the limit but we need that trade setup or system that we can rinse and repeat trades.  
  
I always think a lot of us have it backward we want to risk too much with too little knowledge and then it frustrates us.We could have been building a better system and testing it properly rather than being frustrated by watching an account see-saw up and down.How many years are you planning on trading?I plan on trading till just before I die and so what is 1 or 2 years really when building a system that you know like the back of your hand and can truly leverage to its full potential.  
  
I trade 2 positions at a disaster stop of 15pip ( 2X15 =30) @2.5 % of my account.Looking to one day trade it at 5% of the account but will have to get there slowly  
  
Just my babels - Badly calculated risks spell disaster no matter what industry or environment

I am sure we have to get bigger winners than our losers to be successful traders.  
  
That makes me question this whole scalping mentality that people have of just grabbing a handful of pips per trade. I like the small stops on 1 minute but really want to hold them longer to get the bigger RR, not easy as you know because half the time price comes back and knocks us out for BE.  
  
I am sure the secret lies in trading with the trend and holding until the trend ends, also good times to enter 1 min is after a drive one way say 100 plus pips then catch the first reversal pullback , that way we could get 70 plus pips a typical fib pullback of the original 100pip move down.  
  
Do you ever look back at your days entries to see how far they have run after you exited???  
  
I think it would be cool if we could work out a method to enter on the 1 min looking for a longer hold on TP2, like I say I think it is something like entering on first pullback after a reversal of the 1 min trend, 15min CCI turn. Maybe if we identify the 15min CCI turn is a HL or LH then we should hold the first 1 min entry???  
  
Just a thought.

Heres a thought for anyone who might be interested, every daily candle low or high must start with a 1 minute trend reversal, the problem is which one??  
  
But theres not that many in a day, they are basically 15 min CCI turns or whatever your favourite indy is quite often overbought or oversold indys as per example attached when my 15min CCI becomes oversold.  
  
Now theres gonna be a whole load of false starts and many break even trades but surely its gotta be worth trying to find a Daily candles low or top with a small 1 min stop and maybe a 168 pip reward????  
  
I am going to look at some daily charts that are trending strongly one way then wait for a pullback day, then try to watch out for the 15 min cci turn back with the daily trend. Could catch a nice tight entry and hold on a strong daily trend, now that would be a nice RR worth trying for.  
  
  
Just think about it, every days high or low must be a 1 min reversal, now all we gotta do is find the little so and so's. (Big daydreamer smiley)

Hi Rooi, I wouldn't have flipped exactly. I would almost certainly have been out of the long before the short signal formed using the bar prior to the short signal bar, possibly even the one before that. I would have then entered the short after the signal.   
After the decent run down through the pivot and after it had been straddling it for a while I would have been looking for a possible reversal back towards the pivot but as it was some distance away I'd also be considering any retrace as possible congestion also. And of course a continuation of the current prevailing move. I would therefore be looking at exits in that situation and when we get bars closing the other side of the MA and changing colour like it did, then I have to consider whether I still want to be in the trade (the long, that is).   
Good weekend to you too. strada.

Hi jtrade4u,  
  
Bit late replying as busy weekend and only just saw your post.  
  
You can put a 15 min cci on your 1 min screen very easily, its just a matter of a mathematical calculation. I use a 14 period CCI on my 1 min timeframe so thats my base CCI period, now if I want a 14 period 15min CCI on my 1 min chart as above then all I do is times 14 (cci period) by the timeframe I want, in this case 15 min so 14 x 15 = 210.  
  
  
Then I just put a cci indy on 1 min timeframe set to 210. Its that simple and of course if I want to see the 1 hour CCI under that then its 14x60=840.Example of such a chart below the idea is very similar to the guys here where you trade in the same direction as the higher timeframes when the 1 min CCI pulls back against the 15 and 1 hour trends "hit it" so as chart below shows 1 hr and 15 min CCIs are trading down so sell any 1 min CCI signals.  
  
Hope that helps?  
  
By the way I am soon gonna start my own Trading Systems thread based around these ideas, hopefully monday time permitting, so if you're interested in this idea keep an eye out for it.

Hi  
  
Well to answer your first question I think its more about a straight through broker than a market maker but thats just my opinion.  
  
As for your other question, well, I would say follow the 15 min CCI if trading the 1 min chart.  
  
You also need to understand how the guy who designed the CCI indicator wanted it to work. Basically anything over 100 level is considered a strong trend and you should trade in that direction so if the 15 min CCI (210) is above the 100 level then look to take the 1 min cci (14) signals.  
  
Let me give you some examples see chart below where the 15 min CCI is over -100 level then the 1 min CCI signals are pretty good, one proviso I tend to use is if selling 1 min CCIs then the signal you're taking should be level with or lower than the previous cci signal.  
  
I also look to sell the 1 min signals once the the 15min CCI moves below the +100 level but moving downwards. Just make sure the 1 min CCI signals are level or lower than the previous one. EG only sell double tops or lower highs.As you can see out of the 8 signals 7 are winners and just 1 loser.  
  
Good enough for an edge I'd say wouldn't you??

Hi maxs2002  
  
If you like using the 14 period on your base chart then just times it by the timeframe you want above it. EG 14 x 5 = 70.  
  
But to be honest I find it works best when you maintain an approx ratio of 15 to 1 between the time frames so I recommend as follows for each timeframe:  
  
trading 1 min use 15 min as master (14 and 210)  
trading 5 min use 1hr as master (14 and 168)  
trading 15 min use 4hr as master (14 and 224)  
trading 1hr use daily as master (14 and 336)  
trading 4hr use weekly as master ( 14 and 504)  
trading daily use monthly as master (14 and 350)  
  
Its not an exact science but the logic behind it is that the momentum runs on say a daily chart are a down trend on the hrly chart so if daily pair falling off the page then sell the pullbacks(-100 CCI signals) on the hrly chart.  
  
The single most important thing though is that you identify a strong trend before trading any pair as you will find momentum indicators are fairly accurate in a strong trending pair. eg top of the top 8 trenders indy.  
  
Then look at hrly chart and sell the pullbacks against the trend.Of course all trends come to an end at sometime so you are almost guaranteed a loser at the end but stop taking the hrly cci's when daily CCI crosses down from the -100 level as trend is weakening.  
  
Its all about momentum for me, look at attached chart shows EURAUD as top of the daily trenders so sell every 100cci signal thats over 100 and either a double top or Lower High. Use HA candle colour change as confirmation for entry.  
  
Anyway will shortly start my own thread on this system as starting to hog Roois thread and thats simply bad etiquette so will be moving on soon. Apologies Rooi.

On the Broker issue I personally much prefer ECN brokers , commissions are expensive to offset the tighter [spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide") but for me the fills are far more reliable. The bigger the lot size traded makes it more economical on ECN to the point that it will far outweigh even the tightest fixed spread of a dealing desk broker. That's Just my take, spreads and commissions are a big concern with 1 minute trading. Comments on this welcome.

I missed all 3  
  
I enter short when the MA cross filter is red, and price closes below the MA band with a Stochastic cross down, reverse for long entries, very simple basic rules, but higher probability is when price breaks out of the bands or bounces off the bands.  
  
I narrowly missed the GU break to the upside and got in on GJ bounce off the MA band but exited when I saw a divergence brewing against my position (it would have hit my SL)

Good morning all.  
  
I've come to believe quite frankly that not taking ALL your signals is the #1 reason for failure in trading.  
Everyday I review the charts and I see how I'd have ended up in super positive had I taken ALL my signals instead I let pain of loss keep me from pulling the trigger again and again and recently I've come to identify DISTRACTION as another enemy.  
  
I took a EJ short straight from the FO and it went against me I'd have taken the GJ and GU longs but having committed myself to one position I don't bother with other signals (that would be over trading with my leverage size) they all did well except the EJ and I had to attend an end of month brief so I missed my chance to recover and make profit.  
  
Anyway next week I should have a new ECN account up and running.  
  
Have a great week end everybody and congrats to all who ended the month in +ve.

Thanks Rooi I appreciate your concern it's tough leaving certainty for uncertainty, I mean to the left the market is so lucrative but to the right you never know what can happen the next second, I've seen 80 pips spikes in less than 1 minute and at such times it's very difficult to guarantee your SL being honored and trading with 1 pip = 1%, that could end up an 80% loss in one swoop. Trading the markets full time is like learning to swim with great white, and tiger sharks without being eaten alive, but many have learned how to and I'm about to join them.  
  
I keep saying that my attention to Forex affects my job and my job demands affects my performance in the markets.  
Everyday looking back at the charts I see that had I taken every single one of my M1 signals I'd have ended up above my daily target.  
  
I wont say I have this Forex thing all figured out but I've come to realize technical methods work some of the time, so take the wins with the losses and you will end up a net winner if you STICK TO THE PLAN!  
  
I will work the FO and LO and give it at least 3 months June being a gestation or moratorium period and you'll be here to monitor my progress as well, we are in this thing together ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)  
  
I'm happy my "Just over broke" (job) is not a well paying job, else I may have given up the struggle to make it in Forex!

My friend and I hired a programmer on the Mq4 Mq5 website where programmers will bid for various jobs once an MT4 user posts his requests. When completed you will test the EA to your liking and specifications and only then will the payment process be completed. Its like an escrow account where funds will be held and released. We never paid more then $50 dollars for a completed EA however the more advanced it is, it could cost more.
